Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved. For any repeat violations,
why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024 .
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Public Act 116. 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination
Section of conditions, books, records, and reports; access by department,
Description bureau of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided to
department; failure of licensee to cooperate with investigation,
inspection, or examination.
(1) The department may investigate, inspect, and examine conditions of
a childcare organization and may investigate and examine the
licensee's books and records…
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the department, and
encouraging witnesses, such as staff and household members, to
provide accurate and truthful information to the department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Care Worker documented contacts with foster family which are
believed to be fraudulent.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed by phone on 1/26/2024. Complainant
reported an investigation regarding Foster Parent was assigned on
1/4/2024 at 3:45PM. Complainant reached out to the agency and was
informed someone completed a home visit at the Foster Parent’s house
on 1/4/2024 to verify wellbeing of the child. Complainant found a
contact entered in MiSACWIS, indicating a face-to-face visit occurred,
in the foster home, on 1/4/2024 at 4:20PM. The contact stated the
youth was observed in the foster home, and allegations were discussed
with Foster Parent. Complainant contacted Foster Parent regarding the
investigation and asked if the agency discussed the allegations at the
home visit. Foster Parent indicated to Complainant that no one from the
agency went to their house on 1/4/2024. Complainant reported Foster
Care Supervisor (FCS) was contacted via email to confirm the visit was
completed at the foster home. FCS responded that a home visit was
completed by Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW1) with Foster Parent and the
youth on 1/4/2024. Complainant provided DCWL with a copy of the
email with FCS, a screenshot of the 1/4/2024 MiSACWIS case contact,
and the text messages of the foster parent denying a home visit
occurred. Complainant stated the 1/4/2024 MiSACWIS contact was
later edited by the agency to reflect it was a video conference, not a
face-to-face home visit. The edit was made after Complainant informed
the agency and DHHS of the discrepancy.
2

DHHS Staff was interviewed via TEAMS on 1/29/2024. DHHS Staff
reported she was aware of the allegation and it was accurate. A
complaint was received on 1/4/2024 regarding Foster Parent. A
concern was later reported to DHHS that the agency began an
investigation without coordinating with children’s services. This
prompted DHHS Staff to look at case contacts, where it was observed a
face-to-face home visit occurred with Foster Parent on 1/4/2024, noting
the allegation was discussed. DHHS Staff emailed with FCS, who
confirmed a home visit had occurred on 1/4/2024. DHHS Staff was later
informed by children’s services that Foster Parent indicated a home
visit did not occur on that date. DHHS Staff looked at the contact in
MiSACWIS and observed the 1/4/2024 contact had been changed to
reflect “video conference” instead of face-to-face home visit. DHHS
Staff informed the agency Program Manager and Chief Administrator of
the concern regarding false documentation.
Foster Parent was interviewed by phone on 1/29/2024.
Foster Parent reported that a home visit was not completed on
1/4/2024. FCW1 completed a video call on that date. Foster Parent
stated the only agency staff she saw in person in January was a
licensing worker that visited with children’s services on 1/11/2024 for an
investigation, then another agency staff on 1/17/2024 to move the
youth. Foster Parent reported she accepted placement of the youth on
11/8/2023. A former foster care worker, (FCW2) who is no longer with
the agency, completed placement paperwork during a home visit about
a week later. Foster Parent could not recall any other home visits
completed by agency staff. Foster Parent stated no one came out to
visit in December 2023. Foster Parent recalled FCW2 completed a
video call and saw the youth at the agency previously, but never visited
the youth in the home. Foster Parent stated FCW1 was just recently
assigned and had not been to the home. Follow-up email contact
occurred on 1/30/24 with Foster Parent as a review of case contacts
found that a foster home visit was documented in MiSACWIS for
12/4/2023. Foster Parent stated that she had several texts with FCW2
that day, but a home visit did not occur on that date.
Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed via TEAMS on 1/31/2024.
FCW1 reported that children’s services asked her to complete a home
visit and set up a safety plan, as a new investigation was starting.
FCW1 intended to go to the foster home on 1/4/2024. However, she did
not have her car. FCW1 did not want to cancel the visit and decided to
complete a virtual visit. FCW1 reported that she later, mistakenly,
entered the contact as “face-to-face” rather than virtual. FCW1 said
FCS was aware it was a virtual visit and not in person, as she knew
about FCW1s car problem. FCW1 stated FCS likely told DHHS that a
visit was completed, as she was aware a virtual visit occurred. FCW1
3

clarified that she knew a virtual visit was not the same as an in-person
visit to the home. FCW1 reported that it is a requirement for foster care
staff to have home visit sheets completed and signed by the foster
parent for every visit.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via TEAMS on 1/31/2024.
FCS reported that she and FCW1 spoke about the need for a home
visit to occur, due to the new special evaluation. FCW1 stated she was
going to go out to the home on 1/4/2024. FCS was aware FCW1 had
car trouble, but believed she was borrowing a car as she had done
previously. FCS stated when FCW1 said she was going out to the
home, she did not have any reason to doubt her. FCW1 had always
been someone to follow through and do what is required. A few days
later, DHHS Staff contacted FCS and asked if a visit occurred. FCS
answered yes, as she believed FCW1 had gone to the foster home on
1/4/2024. Later, during supervision, FCS was reviewing cases with
FCW1 and referenced the home visit. FCW1 stated she did not go out
to the home but completed a video call instead. FCS informed FCW1
that MiSACWIS showed a face-to-face visit at the foster home. FCW1
appeared to be unaware and stated it was an error. FCS instructed her
to correct the case contact. FCS stated that she has since discussed
with FCW1 that she must report any change in plans. FCW1 was also
advised to double check any contacts that are entered.
FCS was asked about the 12/4/2023 visit completed by FCW2, FCS
stated she believed the visit occurred as she recalled the worker
complaining about getting home late. However, FCS was not present
for the visit, so she could not say for sure. FCS stated workers are
required to complete a foster home visit form with foster parent
signature at every home visit. FCS was asked to locate the December
2023 form and provide it to DCWL. On 2/7/2024, FCS reported that she
was unable to locate a home visit from for 12/4/2023.
Chief Administrator was interviewed by phone on 1/31/2024
Chief Administrator (CA) was aware of the allegation. CA spoke with
FCS to ensure the 1/4/2024 contact was now documented accurately in
MiSACWIS. CA stated there have been no prior concerns with FCW1s
performance. CA believed the contact was accidentally entered
incorrectly by FCW1. However, an internal investigation was in
progress. CA was informed that it appeared a December 2023 home
visit may have been entered when it did not occur. This contact was
entered by staff that was no longer with the agency. CA was unsure if
all staff were using foster home visit forms. A follow-up phone call
occurred on 2/14/2024, in which CA shared the findings of her internal
investigation and was informed of the findings for this investigation.
Potential action steps for the CAP were discussed.
4

Documents Reviewed
• Email dated 1/5/2024 at 9:02AM, agency was informed of
investigation by children’s services.
• MiSACWIS screenshot of case contact entered on 1/5/2024 at
10:08AM, by FCW1. Contact indicated a foster home visit, on
1/4/2024, for 45-60 minutes, face-to-face, at the foster home at
4:20PM. “home visit in child’s residence” was marked. Narrative
stated a home visit occurred, allegations were discussed with
Foster Parent, youth was present.
• MiSACWIS case contact for 1/4/2024, was viewed on 1/26/2024.
The contact had been edited to indicate the visit was a video
conference, not a face-to-face home visit.
• Text between Complainant and Foster Parent. Foster Parent
reported a virtual visit occurred on 1/4/2024, not a home visit.
• 1/10/2024 emails from FCS to Complainant and DHHS stating
“We met with (Foster Parent) on January 4, 2024, for a home
visit” and “The home visit was completed on the evening of the
4th”.
• MiSACWIS case contact for 12/4/2023 indicated a home visit
occurred at the foster home, with the youth and Foster Parent.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed, it was determined
agency staff inaccurately documented in MiSACWIS that a foster home
visit occurred on 1/4/2024. In addition, another foster home visit on
12/4/2023 was entered into MiSACWIS but could not be verified.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
